## 판결문 요약

461 F.2d 721
    UNITED STATES of Americav.George J. HYKEL et al.
    No. 71-2091.
    United States Court of Appeals,Third Circuit.
    Argued March 23, 1972.Decided May 23, 1972.
    
      F. Emmett Fitzpatrick, Jr., Fitzpatrick & Smith, Philadelphia, Pa., for appellant.
      C. Oliver Burt, III, Asst. U. S. Atty., Louis C. Bechtle, U. S. Atty., Philadelphia, Pa., for appellee.
      Before SEITZ, Chief Judge, and ADAMS and HUNTER, Circuit Judges.
      OPINION OF THE COURT
      HUNTER, Circuit Judge.
    
    
      1
      Appellant George J. Hykel was convicted for violating 18 U.S.C. Sec. 1006, which forbids, inter alia, officers of federally-insured savings and loan associations from participating "directly or indirectly" in any loan by the savings and loan association, with intent to defraud.1  It is argued on this appeal that the evidence was insufficient to support the conviction, and that certain of the District Court's evidentiary rulings require a new trial.  We find these arguments without merit, and accordingly affirm.
    
    I. SUFFICIENCY OF THE EVIDENCE
    
      2
      18 U.S.C. Sec. 1006 provides, in relevant part:
